moves.1. d4: White chooses a Queen opening to push aggressively into my territory
moves.2. Nf3: a knight attack to win the sweet center of the board
moves.2... e6: but I start my opening routine unconcerned
moves.3. Bd2: white is moving major pieces out, a good strategy, but I must continue to build my house for the king
moves.3... Nf6: this move is an example of that strategy
moves.5. Nc3: white continues to develop major pieces, a good strategy
moves.7. Ng5: white is pressing the attack. Now she has moved a major piece twice and the opening is still in full swing. This is a premature move and easily foiled.
moves.8. Qf3: noiw white brings out her queen. This is really early in my opinion given the board. Lots of opportunity to lose the queen under the circumstances.
moves.8... b6: Ibegin to lay a trap for the queen
moves.9. Qh3: white is thinking "checkmate". but again, not enough development has occurred and this is easily turned back
moves.10. Nxd5: white brings force to the attack - a good strategy
moves.10... Nxd5: but unguarded the knight is captured, this is a grevious error
moves.11... Qxg5: now this is a strange move..why not take the knight?
moves.13. a4: good, an attack in the middle is best arepelled by an attack on the flank
moves.14. Qh4: white is positioning her queen for a major assault
moves.14... Qxg2: and in so doing, gives up a pawn.
moves.15. Ke2: now she has to move defensively to protect her castle
moves.15... Qf3+: I am trying to get her to drop back to the first row so I can capture a rook...
moves.16... Qf5: but I think I sense danger if I do that...so I drop back
moves.17. Bxd7: now why did white not capture a rook here? Because she was trying to ensure a mate with her Bishop and Queen I believe.
moves.17... Red8: so instead, I will threaten her
moves.18. Qe7: a good move to bring the Queen into the attack, but my King is in his castle, and well protected.
moves.19. Bb4: this IS dangerous...but again, as I assess the situation, premature. There is no way for her to mate me in the current allignment as far as I can tell.
moves.19... Qh3+: So I try to control the game by keeping her King in check and manouvering him to a certain mate
moves.22... Qxh2: Hmmm stymied....I have to regroup..actually, this was a wasted move. A move to h4 would have been swifter
moves.24. Bxe6: even with all this fire power, I cannot see white achieving mate in this configuration.
moves.24... fxe6: and to sacrifice a Bishop for a pawn is another mistake.
moves.25. Qxe6+: even with this, I am not concerned.
moves.25... Kh8: my King is almost invulnerable in this situation.
moves.26. Bxf8: but a good capture leads to...
moves.27. Rf7: so how to capture my King...this move is not a bad move, in that it brings force to the battle, but it is not enough given the nature of my defense
moves.27... Rd8: I start to think about mate...
moves.29. e4: Aah the opening I have been waiting for.
moves.30. Kc4: the King is forced into trouble
moves.30... Bxe4: one move away from mate, white resigns... a good game marked by a couple of mistakes and attacks that occur too early in development with not enough force easily repelled and taken advantage of.
